article.title: Telecommunications_in_Eritrea
article.paragraph: Telecommunications in Eritreaare under the authority of theGovernment of Eritrea.
article.heading: Infrastructure
article.paragraph: TheEritrean Telecommunications CorporationEritrea Telecommunication Services Corporation, more commonly known asEriTel, is the sole operator of both landline and mobile telephone communication infrastructure inEritrea. However, it is one of severalinternet service providersin the country."Eritrea Telecommunication Services Corporation (EriTel)", International Telecommunications Union (ITU), 2011. Retrieved 1 November 2013.

The domestic telecommunications infrastructure is very inadequate. Most fixed line telephones are located inAsmara, the capital and largest city. Cell phones are in increasing use throughout the country. The government is seeking international tenders to improve the system.

On 13 April 2006, Eritrea received a soft loan from the government ofChinato upgrade their communication infrastructure. The total sum loaned toEriTelwas $23 million. All major cities are connected to the mobile telephone system in Eritrea except for Nakfa, Afabet, and Asseb. Afabet and Nakfa are expected to be online by July 2006.update after2013111
article.heading: Telephones

list.listitem: Fixed phones in use: 58,500 lines, 159th in the world (2011)."Eritrea",World Factbook, U.S. Central Intelligence Agency. Retrieved 31 November 2013.
Mobile cellular phones in use: 241,900 lines, 175th in the world (2011).
Combined fixed-line and mobile-cellular subscribership is less than 5 per 100 persons (2011).

article.heading: Radio and television

list.listitem: The government controls all broadcast media with private ownership prohibited. Purchases of satellite dishes and subscriptions to international broadcast media are permitted.

article.heading: Internet censorship and surveillance

list.listitem: Listed as Under Surveillance byReporters Without Borders(RWB) in 2008, 2009, not in 2010, and again from 2011 to the present.''Internet Enemies'', Reporters Without Borders (Paris), 12 March 2012

article.paragraph: Eritrea has not set up a widespread automatic Internet filtering system, but it does not hesitate to order blocking of several diaspora websites critical of the regime. Access to these sites is blocked by two of the Internet service providers, Erson and Ewan, as arepornographicwebsites andYouTube.Self-censorshipis said to be widespread."Countries under surveillance: Eritrea", Reporters Without Borders, March 2011
